CatDescriptText: Mr. Fred Coleman, 2100 Glen Mawr Ave., Sheridan and Miss Edith Henry, 3237 Penn Avenue, Lawrenceville, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 16, 1957, pg. 1, with question: "Do you believe we should have a state law forbidding stricks of trolley cars, buses, and taxicabs?" Mr. Fred Coleman answer reads: "I'm for a no-strike law. My reason is because that when such things as trolleys, buses, and taxicabs strike, they make things tough for the majority of people.  For instance, my sister-in-law has to go all the way to Sheridan each day for work."  Miss Edith Henry answer reads: "I think there should be a law.  People have to depend very much on these things, and especially the street cars, to get back and forth to work."
TitMainTitle: Group portrait of Fred Coleman, and Edith Henry holding plaid umbrella, standing in front of automobiles and a brick building with sign that reads "T ...ITAL"
